metadata.sermon_start_end: “I cannot bear either your fasts or your festivals!” [Is 1:13] Through these words of Isaiah’s, the Holy Spirit reprimands people who obstinately cling to their imperfections. The fasting which pleases the Most High consists not only in cutting down on food but also in cutting out all evil deeds. [...] Eagerly offer hospitality to those with no roof over their head, so that God may receive you into his kingdom, through Christ Jesus our Lord, to whom belong glory and honor for ever and ever. Amen.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses two distinct passages from Isaiah as a thematic springboard rather than recreating a specific pericope into a new word. It fails Dekker's requirement of focusing on one specific passage to find what is 'nowhere else in the Bible.' Instead, it treats the text as a source for a general moral discourse on fasting.
quotes: Through these words of Isaiah’s, the Holy Spirit reprimands people...
That’s exactly what we read in Isaiah...
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one specific pericope (e.g., only Is 58:5-9) and explore its unique linguistic and prophetic tension rather than using it to validate a pre-existing moral concept.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no evidence of historical-critical or linguistic engagement. The original context of Israel's cultic failure or the socio-political reality of the post-exilic community is absent. The text is treated as a timeless moral handbook.
quotes: The fasting which pleases the Most High consists not only in cutting down on food but also in cutting out all evil deeds.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the specific historical context of Isaiah's audience to explain why their specific 'fasts and festivals' were rejected by God, moving beyond general 'imperfections'.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete in terms of actions (feeding the hungry, clothing the naked) but remains general in its address. It lacks engagement with the specific 'zeitgeist' or the contemporary socio-economic complexities of the modern hearer.
quotes: sharing your bread with the hungry, sheltering the oppressed and the homeless, clothing the naked
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Translate the biblical 'naked' and 'homeless' into specific contemporary categories relevant to the congregation's immediate social or political environment.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon avoids a strict 'first half theory, second half practice' split. The moral application is woven into the reading of the text, though this is largely because the text itself is being read as a moral imperative.
quotes: Perform the works of mercy, therefore, and you’ll sanctify your fasts.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Deepen the 'exposition' side so that the 'application' feels like a necessary discovery from the text's depths rather than a repetition of its surface-level commands.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon leans heavily on a form of 'misery' (sin) and 'gratitude' (good works), but it risks becoming legalistic. Redemption is presented almost as a reward for good works ('acquire a stronger title to God’s favor') rather than a gift received.
quotes: you’ll acquire a stronger title to God’s favor.
Clothe the naked, and your sins will be covered.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Reframe the 'three parts' so that good works are an outflow of gratitude for a redemption already accomplished, rather than a means to achieve it.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon strongly emphasizes the seriousness of human choice and the possibility of being 'disgusting' to God. It takes the hearer seriously as a responsible being whose actions determine their standing before the Divine.
quotes: not only will you fail to please God, but you will positively fill him with disgust.
so that God may receive you into his kingdom
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Clarify the 'lostness' not just as a failure of ritual, but as a fundamental ontological risk in the face of God's holiness.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned only at the very end as a liturgical formula. He is not the 'telos' of the sermon; the human act of fasting and mercy is the telos. The sermon lacks the 'solus Christus' depth Dekker demands.
quotes: Such is the fasting which Christ Jesus desires...
through Christ Jesus our Lord, to whom belong glory and honor for ever and ever.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Integrate Christ as the one who fulfilled the 'true fast' on our behalf, making him the source of the power to perform works of mercy, not just a name at the conclusion.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 650 words, the sermon would last roughly 6-7 minutes. This is far below Dekker's 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for 'depth'.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the analysis of the text and the complexity of the human condition to reach a length that allows for substantive theological reflection.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its brevity, its moralistic tone, and its lack of Christological depth. It functions more as a moral exhortation than a theological exposition of the Word of God. The specific 'present' of revelation is missing because the text is used to demand human performance rather than to proclaim God's act in Christ.
strengths: Strong emphasis on the 'two ways' and the seriousness of human responsibility.
Avoids a clinical separation between text and life, maintaining a direct address to the hearer.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (under 7 minutes) prevents any real depth or breadth.
Legalistic tendency: suggests that sins are 'covered' by human works of mercy rather than by grace.
Lack of specific exegesis: no engagement with the original context or the unique voice of Isaiah.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the sense of Dekker's definition. It is a brief moral address. It fails to treat the Bible passage as the unique Word of God that says something found 'nowhere else,' opting instead for general religious truths about piety and charity.
